issue.title: Port parsing can overflow (TOB-K8S-015: Overflows when using strconv.Atoi and downcasting the result)
issue.body: This issue was reported in the [Kubernetes Security Audit Report](https://github.com/kubernetes/community/blob/master/wg-security-audit/findings/Kubernetes%20Final%20Report.pdf)rnrn**Description**rnThe strconv.Atoi function parses an int - a machine dependent integer type, which, for 64-bit targets will be int64. There are places throughout the codebase where the result returned from strconv.Atoi is later converted to a smaller type: int16 or int32. This may overflow with a certain input. An example of the issue has been included in Figure 1.rnrn```rnv, err := strconv.Atoi(options.DiskMBpsReadWrite)rndiskMBpsReadWrite = int32(v)rn```rnFigure 13.1: pkg/cloudprovider/providers/azure/azure_managedDiskController.go:105rnrnAdditionally, there are many code paths that parse ports, and do so differently and in a manner lacking checks for a proper port range. An example of this has been identified within kubectl when handling port values.rnrnKubectl has the ability to expose particular Pod ports through the use of kubectl expose. This command uses the function updatePodPorts, which uses strconv.Atoi to parse a string into an integer, then downcasts it to an int32 (Figure 2).rnrn```rn// updatePodContainers updates PodSpec.Containers.Ports with passed parameters.rnfunc updatePodPorts(params map[string]string, podSpec *v1.PodSpec) (err error) {rn    port := -1rn    hostPort := -1rn    if len(params['port']) > 0 {rn        port, err = strconv.Atoi(params['port']) // <-- this should parse port as strconv.ParseUint(params['port'], 10, 16)rn        if err != nil {rn            return errrn        }rn    }rn       // (...)rn    // Don't include the port if it was not specified.rn    if len(params['port']) > 0 {rn        podSpec.Containers[0].Ports = []v1.ContainerPort{rn            {rn                ContainerPort: int32(port), // <-- this should later just be uint16(port)rn            },rn        }rn```rnFigure 13.2: Relevant snippet of the updatePodPorts function.rnrnThis error has been operationalized into a crash within kubectl when overflowing provided ports. Starting with a standard deployment with no services, we can observe the expected behavior (Figure 3).rnrn```rnroot@k8s-1:~# cat nginx.ymlrnapiVersion: apps/v1 # for versions before 1.9.0 use apps/v1beta2rnkind: Deploymentrnmetadata:rn  name: nginx-deploymentrnspec:rn  selector:rn    matchLabels:rn      app: nginxrn  replicas: 1 # tells deployment to run 2 pods matching the templatern  template:rn    metadata:rn      labels:rn        app: nginxrn    spec:rn      containers:rn      - name: nginxrn        image: nginx:1.7.9rn        ports:rn        - containerPort: 80rn        rnroot@k8s-1:~# kubectl create -f nginx.ymlrndeployment.apps/nginx-deployment createdrnrnroot@k8s-1:~# kubectl get podsrnNAME                                READY   STATUS    RESTARTS   AGErnnginx-deployment-76bf4969df-nskjh   1/1     Running   0          2m14srnrnroot@k8s-1:~# kubectl get servicesrnNAME         TYPE        CLUSTER-IP   EXTERNAL-IP   PORT(S)   AGErnkubernetes   ClusterIP   10.233.0.1   <none>        443/TCP   30mrn```rnFigure 13.3: The deployment spec with service and Pod status.rnrnTo trigger the overflow, we can now update the deployment through the kubectl expose command with an overflown port, overflowing from 4294967377 to 81 (Figure 4).rn```rnroot@k8s-1:/home/vagrant# kubectl expose deployment nginx-deployment --port 4294967377 --target-port 80rnservice/nginx-deployment exposedrn```rnFigure 13.4: Overflowing the port parameter.rnrnWe are now able to observe this overflown port when listing the services with kubectl get services (Figure 5). We are also able to access the service on the overflown port (Figure 6).rn```rnroot@k8s-1:/home/vagrant# kubectl get servicesrnNAME               TYPE        CLUSTER-IP      EXTERNAL-IP   PORT(S)   AGErnkubernetes         ClusterIP   10.233.0.1      <none>        443/TCP   42mrnnginx-deployment   ClusterIP   10.233.25.138   <none>        81/TCP    2srn```rnFigure 13.5: The overflown port got exposed.rnrn```rnroot@k8s-1:/home/vagrant# curl 10.233.25.138:81rn<!DOCTYPE html>rn<html>rn<head>rn<title>Welcome to nginx!</title>rn...rn```rnFigure 13.6: The result of curling the overflown service port.rnrnFurthering this issue,  we are able to also overflow the target port. After deleting the service, we can attempt to overflow the target port as well, which will result in a panic in kubectl (Figure 7 and 8).rnrn```rnroot@k8s-1:/home/vagrant# kubectl delete service nginx-deploymentrnservice 'nginx-deployment' deletedrnroot@k8s-1:/home/vagrant# kubectl get servicesrnNAME         TYPE        CLUSTER-IP   EXTERNAL-IP   PORT(S)   AGErnkubernetes   ClusterIP   10.233.0.1   <none>        443/TCP   45mrn```rnFigure 13.7: The deletion of the deployment.rnrn```rnroot@k8s-1:/home/vagrant# kubectl expose deployment nginx-deployment --port 4294967377 --target-port 4294967376rnE0402 09:25:31.888983    3625 intstr.go:61] value: 4294967376 overflows int32rngoroutine 1 [running]:rnruntime/debug.Stack(0xc000e54eb8, 0xc4f1e9b8, 0xa3ce32e2a3d43b34)rnt/usr/local/go/src/runtime/debug/stack.go:24 +0xa7rnk8s.io/kubernetes/vendor/k8s.io/apimachinery/pkg/util/intstr.FromInt(0x100000050, 0xa, 0x100000050, 0x0, 0x0)rn...rnservice/nginx-deployment exposedrn```rnFigure 13.8: The panic in kubectl when overflowing the target port.rnrnDespite the panic from kubectl (visible in Figure 8), the service is still exposed (Figure 9) and accessible (Figure 10).rn```rnroot@k8s-1:/home/vagrant# kubectl get servicesrnNAME               TYPE        CLUSTER-IP      EXTERNAL-IP   PORT(S)   AGErnkubernetes         ClusterIP   10.233.0.1      <none>        443/TCP   46mrnnginx-deployment   ClusterIP   10.233.59.190   <none>        81/TCP    35srn```rnFigure 13.9: The service is exposed despite the kubectl panic and overflow.rnrn```rnroot@k8s-1:/home/vagrant# curl 10.233.59.190:81rn<!DOCTYPE html>rn<html>rn<head>rn<title>Welcome to nginx!</title>rn...rn```rnFigure 13.10: The service is also accessible after overflow.rnrn**Exploit Scenario**rnA value is parsed from a configuration file with Atoi, resulting in an integer. It is then downcasted to a lower precision value, resulting in a potential overflow or underflow which is not raised as an error or panic.rnrn**Recommendation**rnShort term, when parsing strings into fixed-width integer types, use strconv.ParseInt or strconv.ParseUint with appropriate bitSize argument instead of strconv.Atoi.rnrnLong term, ensure the validity of data and types. Parse and validate values with common functions. For example the ParsePort (cmd/kubeadm/app/util/endpoint.go:117) utility function parses and validates TCP port values, but it is not well used across the codebase.rnrn**Anything else we need to know?**:rnrnSee #81146 for current status of all issues created from these findings.rnrnThe vendor gave this issue an ID of TOB-K8S-015 and it was finding 13 of the report.rnrnThe vendor considers this issue Medium Severity.rnrnTo view the original finding, begin on page 42 of the [Kubernetes Security Review Report](https://github.com/kubernetes/community/blob/master/wg-security-audit/findings/Kubernetes%20Final%20Report.pdf)rnrn**Environment**:rnrn- Kubernetes version: 1.13.4

issue.title: Add unit tests for Scheduler framework
issue.body: <!-- Please only use this template for submitting enhancement requests -->rnrn**What would you like to be added**:rnAdd unit tests for Scheduler [framework](https://github.com/congliu01/kubernetes/blob/73704f1b8e04c573185f230019cc1891375c283b/pkg/scheduler/framework/v1alpha1/framework.go#L264). rnrnCurrently there are only [integration tests](https://github.com/congliu01/kubernetes/blob/c54c4d1962d84b0659644f8ae9c9976b547d021f/test/integration/scheduler/framework_test.go#L435-L434) for the framework. rnrn**Why is this needed**:rn* Unit tests are easier to write and maintain. rnrnThe integration tests requires spawning up etcd and the scheduler reconcile loop, which includes way more logic than the framework itself. It's also hard to control and inspect the input/output easily due to the fact that the Scheduler is a 'black box' during integration test. As a result, we can find tests that are really hard to understand and maintain, see [example](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/issues/80227)rnrn* Unit tests can run fast and deterministically.rnrnDue to the asynchronous and 'black box' nature of running the Scheduler reconcile loop, the current integration tests takes longer time and flaky. Here is a recent [example](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/issues/80255) of this.rnrn* Unit tests can potentially cover more cases than integration tests.rnrnAgain, it's hard to control and inspect the system state running integration test. For example, it's not possible to inspect the full output of the Score plugin with integration test.rn

issue.title: Different Webhook with same name have same label-value in metric webhook_admission_duration_seconds
issue.body: **What happened**:rnrnDifferent Webhook with same name have same label-value in metric `webhook_admission_duration_seconds`. For now, we can add two or more Webhooks using the same name. Webhooks with same name will get the same label-value in metric `webhook_admission_duration_seconds` and record different Webhooks into the same label-value metric.rnrn**What you expected to happen**:rnrnDifference Webhooks which have same name using their AdmissionConfiguration(MutatingWebhookConfiguration or ValidatingWebhookConfiguration) name. Add a new label `configuration_name` to metric `webhook_admission_duration_seconds`.rnrn**How to reproduce it (as minimally and precisely as possible)**:rnrnCreate two MutatingWebhookConfiguration which have same Webhook name like the flowing codes:rnrn```yamlrnapiVersion: admissionregistration.k8s.io/v1beta1rnkind: MutatingWebhookConfigurationrnmetadata:rn  name: mutating-arnwebhooks:rn  - name: mutating-pod.k8s.iorn...rn---rnrnapiVersion: admissionregistration.k8s.io/v1beta1rnkind: MutatingWebhookConfigurationrnmetadata:rn  name: mutating-brnwebhooks:rn  - name: mutating-pod.k8s.iorn...rn```rnrn**Anything else we need to know?**:rnrnNothing yet.rnrn**Environment**:rnrnNo cares about that.

issue.title: Support UDP with AWS NLB
issue.body: **What happened**:rn```Error creating load balancer (will retry): failed to ensure load balancer for service default/test: Only TCP LoadBalancer is supported for AWS ELB```rnrn**What you expected to happen**: kubernetes creating an AWS NLB for UDP rnrn**How to reproduce it (as minimally and precisely as possible)**: Create service with annotation `service.beta.kubernetes.io/aws-load-balancer-type: nlb` and port with `protocol: UDP`rnrn**Anything else we need to know?**:rnAWS recently announced that UDP is available within their NLB https://aws.amazon.com/de/blogs/aws/new-udp-load-balancing-for-network-load-balancer/rnrn**Environment**:rn- Kubernetes version (use `kubectl version`): 1.11.9rn- Cloud provider or hardware configuration: AWS

issue.title: Connect lower level traces to surrounding request handling trace
issue.body: <!-- Please only use this template for submitting enhancement requests -->rnrn**What would you like to be added**:rnrnThe kube-apiserver logs traces for operations that exceed a max latency using the `k8s.io/utils/trace` utility. This is done for request handling, etcd storage layer operations, watch cache operations and we just added it for webhook calls.rnrnBut when, for example, there is a create request that involves high latency admission webhook call, there are two separate traces logged: rnrnOne for the create request being handled:rnrn```rnTrace[866828359]: 'Create /api/v1/namespaces/default/pods' (started: 2019-03-11 08:20:14.448210695 +0000 UTC m=+579.430813234) (total time: 14.520559394s):rnTrace[866828359]: [165.764543ms] [149.545551ms] Object stored in databasernTrace[866828359]: [14.304157451s] [14.138392908s] Writing responsernTrace[866828359]: [14.520559394s] [216.401943ms] ENDrn```rnrnAn entirely independent one for the admission webhook call:rnrn```rnTrace[770033805]: 'Call mutating webhook: configuration: mutating.stable.example.com, webhook: noop.stable.example.com, resource: {stable.example.com v1 foos}, subResource: , operation: DELETE, UID: fe7355d4-6c72-459c-9118-b7f43175dac1' (started: 2019-06-11 22:11:59.119388404 +0000 UTC m=+120.935456173) (total time: 12.76491ms):rnTrace[770033805]: [12.754882ms] [12.754882ms] Request completedrn```rnrnIdeally, these would be connected together in some way. In the above example, the admission webhook call is part of the overall create request. I'm not tied to a specific output format, but it would be great to organize the trace logging to make this as obvious as possible, e.g.:rnrn```rnTrace[866828359]: 'Create /api/v1/namespaces/default/pods' (started: 2019-03-11 08:20:14.448210695 +0000 UTC m=+579.430813234) (total time: 14.520559394s):rnTrace[866828359]: Subtrace[770033805]: 'Call mutating webhook: configuration: mutating.stable.example.com, webhook: noop.stable.example.com, resource: {stable.example.com v1 foos}, subResource: , operation: DELETE, UID: fe7355d4-6c72-459c-9118-b7f43175dac1' (started: 2019-06-11 22:11:59.119388404 +0000 UTC m=+120.935456173) (total time: 12.76491ms):rnTrace[866828359]: Subtrace[770033805]: [12.754882ms] [12.754882ms] Request completedrnTrace[866828359]: [165.764543ms] [149.545551ms] Object stored in databasernTrace[866828359]: [14.304157451s] [14.138392908s] Writing responsernTrace[866828359]: [14.520559394s] [216.401943ms] ENDrn```rnrnCurrently, the trace library only provides a way to add steps to a trace, but I feel like hierarchy helps convey the relationships here.rnrn**Why is this needed**:rnrnWould make it much easier to drill down from  a trace message in the kube-apiserver to the component responsible for the high latency of a request.rnrn/sig api-machineryrncc @cheftako @logicalhan

issue.title: FC Plugin Support for Mount Options
issue.body: <!-- Please only use this template for submitting enhancement requests -->rnrn**What would you like to be added**:rnrnCurrently many in-tree storage plugins, including the iSCSI plugin, support mount options. The FC plugin does not. I have poked around the code enough to know where the plugin reports that mount options are not supported, but it isn't clear to me WHY they aren't supported.rnrn**Why is this needed**:rnrnMount options can drastically change the performance and data persistence characteristics of a filesystem. For example, 'noatime' can reduce metadata operations on frequently read data or 'sync' can ensure all writes go immediately down to a backing storage array. I am working on a deployment across an FC backed cluster for which the the containerized application benefits from specific mount options, and I would guess other users might find similar use cases.rnrnIt seems to me that if mount options are supportable on iSCSI, they should be equally supportable on FC, but I certainly recognize the possibility that I may be missing something. Otherwise, I'm guessing they simply haven't been a priority?

issue.title: Update docs to indicate that API values of []byte are always base64-encoded
issue.body: <!-- Please only use this template for submitting enhancement requests -->rnrn**What would you like to be added**:rnExtend the docs the clarify that various places there the API expects `[]byte` that this is base64 encodedrnrn**Why is this needed**:rnI was looking at the 1.13 API docs for the conversion webhook and it saidrnrn```rn`caBundle` is a PEM encoded CA bundle which will be used to validate the webhook's server certificate. If unspecified, system trust roots on the apiserver are used.rn```rnrnIt's not obvious to me that this value should be base64 of the pem encoded contentsrnrn<!-- DO NOT EDIT BELOW THIS LINE -->rn/kind feature

issue.title: change service port with aws nlb uff0cold security group rules not deleted
issue.body: <!-- Please use this template while reporting a bug and provide as much info as possible. Not doing so may result in your bug not being addressed in a timely manner. Thanks!-->rnrnrn**What happened**:rnI deployed a cluster on aws and created a loadbalance type service. When I modify the port of this service, the value of nodeport, loadbalance on aws will only add a new port in the security group, and will not delete the port that was originally opened.rnrn**What you expected to happen**:rnDelete the original opened port, only keep the new portrnrn**How to reproduce it (as minimally and precisely as possible)**:rncreate a service like thisuff1arnsvc.yamlrnkind: ServicernapiVersion: v1rnmetadata:rn  name: my-servicern  annotations:rn    service.beta.kubernetes.io/aws-load-balancer-type: nlbrnspec:rn  selector:rn    app: nginxrn  ports:rn  - name: internet-nlbrn    nodePort: 30080rn    port: 30080rn    protocol: TCPrn    targetPort: 80rn  type: LoadBalancerrnrnthen securiy group will add two rules:rnrnCustom TCP Rule | TCP | 30080 | 0.0.0.0/0 | kubernetes.io/rule...rnrnCustom TCP Rule | TCP | 30080 | 172.31.0.0/16 | kubernetes.io/rule...rnrnthen I modify the service port,change nodeport to 30081,port to 30081rnrnthen securiy group will bernCustom TCP Rule | TCP | 30080 | 0.0.0.0/0 | kubernetes.io/rule...rnrnCustom TCP Rule | TCP | 30080 | 172.31.0.0/16 | kubernetes.io/rule...rnrnCustom TCP Rule | TCP | 30081 | 0.0.0.0/0 | kubernetes.io/rule...rnrnCustom TCP Rule | TCP | 30081 | 172.31.0.0/16 | kubernetes.io/rule...rnrnI think the rules contain 30080 should be removed,no server is open to 30080 nowrnrn**Anything else we need to know?**:rnrn**Environment**:rn- Kubernetes version (use `kubectl version`):rnv1.11.2rn- Cloud provider or hardware configuration:rn- OS (e.g. from /etc/os-release):rnCentOS Linux 7 (Core)rn- Kernel (e.g. `uname -a`):rnLinux enn-2-129 3.10.0-693.el7.x86_64rn- Install tools:rninstall k8s cluster with binary and Configuration file rn- Others:rnrn<!-- DO NOT EDIT BELOW THIS LINE -->rn/kind bug

issue.title: API docs for job status should clearly explain what fields indicate success or failure
issue.body: The API docs for jobs are unclear as to what fields a caller would use to determine job success or failure in 1.11 (and we haven't updated them in a while)rnrn```rn  status:rn    conditions:rn    - lastProbeTime: 2018-09-15T19:51:27Zrn      lastTransitionTime: 2018-09-15T19:51:27Zrn      message: Job has reached the specified backoff limitrn      reason: BackoffLimitExceededrn      status: 'True'rn      type: Failedrn    failed: 6rn    startTime: 2018-09-15T19:46:13Zrn```rnrn```rn$ kubectl explain jobs.statusrnKIND:     JobrnVERSION:  batch/v1rnrnRESOURCE: status <Object>rnrnDESCRIPTION:rn     Current status of a job. More info:rn     https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/api-conventions.md#spec-and-statusrnrn     JobStatus represents the current state of a Job.rnrnFIELDS:rn   activet<integer>rn     The number of actively running pods.rnrn   completionTimet<string>rn     Represents time when the job was completed. It is not guaranteed to be setrn     in happens-before order across separate operations. It is represented inrn     RFC3339 form and is in UTC.rnrn   conditionst<[]Object>rn     The latest available observations of an object's current state. More info:rn     https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/workloads/controllers/jobs-run-to-completion/rnrn   failedt<integer>rn     The number of pods which reached phase Failed.rnrn   startTimet<string>rn     Represents time when the job was acknowledged by the job controller. It isrn     not guaranteed to be set in happens-before order across separatern     operations. It is represented in RFC3339 form and is in UTC.rnrn   succeededt<integer>rn     The number of pods which reached phase Succeeded.rn```rnrnA casual reader would infer that completionTime is set when the job fails (but it isn't).  Linking out to the docs is ok, but I shouldn't have to click through the links to understand how to use the Job object.  The Job description and the job status fields should *clearly* indicate what fields are set in completion states on the job, because that's 100% of the point of docs.  Taking a summary of the jobs-run-to-completion link and putting it in job.status.conditions, job.status, and job would improve the actual utility of our API doc.rnrnWe should also do a pass on other objects and make the actual in server docs more useful.rnrn@kubernetes/sig-apps-bugs

issue.title: kube-proxy: node-port ipv6 port open on v4 cluster
issue.body: /kind bugrnrnrn**What happened**:rnrnWhen creating a node port application (in this case the example guestbook) on a host server that is dual stacked and has AAAA and A DNS entries, the node port on the v6 address is open to kube-proxy and hangs. rnrn**What you expected to happen**:rnrnThe v6 address would refuse the connection and the client would fall back onto the v4 address which would connect correctly.rnrn**How to reproduce it (as minimally and precisely as possible)**:rnrn```rnapiVersion: kubeadm.k8s.io/v1alpha2rnkind: MasterConfigurationrnclusterName: kubernetesrnapi:rn  advertiseAddress: <ipv4 address>rnnetworking:rn  dnsDomain: cluster.localrn  podSubnet: 192.168.0.0/16rn  serviceSubnet: 172.30.0.0/16rnbootstrapTokens:rn  - token: v315ij.jrg9nu08ayho78q7rnkubeProxy:rn  config:rn    mode: ipvsrn    ipvs:rn      scheduler: lcrn```rnrnkubeadm init with the above, and join in some workers. Then install the guestbook application https://kubernetes.io/docs/tutorials/stateless-application/guestbook/rnrnObtain the node port with `kubectl get services frontend` and telnet to one of the servers on that port from a dual stacked client. The client will connect and refuse to respond to 'GET /'rnrntelnet directly to the IPv4 address of the server on the port and all works as expected. rnrn**Anything else we need to know?**:rnrnkube-proxy is noted as listening on the port. rnrn```rnubuntu@srv-jidtj:~$ sudo ss -l -t -p | grep 31759rnLISTEN   0         128                       *:31759                   *:*       users:(('kube-proxy',pid=2268,fd=7))rn```rnrnrn**Environment**:rn- Kubernetes version (use `kubectl version`):rnubuntu@srv-jidtj:~$ kubectl versionrnClient Version: version.Info{Major:'1', Minor:'11', GitVersion:'v1.11.1', GitCommit:'b1b29978270dc22fecc592ac55d903350454310a', GitTreeState:'clean', BuildDate:'2018-07-17T18:53:20Z', GoVersion:'go1.10.3', Compiler:'gc', Platform:'linux/amd64'}rnServer Version: version.Info{Major:'1', Minor:'11', GitVersion:'v1.11.1', GitCommit:'b1b29978270dc22fecc592ac55d903350454310a', GitTreeState:'clean', BuildDate:'2018-07-17T18:43:26Z', GoVersion:'go1.10.3', Compiler:'gc', Platform:'linux/amd64'}rn- Cloud provider or hardware configuration:rnBrightboxrn- OS (e.g. from /etc/os-release):rnUbuntu 18.04.1 LTSrn- Kernel (e.g. `uname -a`):rnLinux srv-jidtj 4.15.0-29-generic #31-Ubuntu SMP Tue Jul 17 15:39:52 UTC 2018 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linuxrn- Install tools:rnkubeadm 1.11rn- Others:rn

issue.title: destroy the 'Expect(err).NotTo(HaveOccurred())' anti-pattern in e2e tests
issue.body: I'm getting tired of seeing flake issues like https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/issues/33647 where every single failure is of the formnn```nExpected error:n    <*errors.errorString | 0xc820412c10>: {n        s: 'timed out waiting for the condition',n    }n    timed out waiting for the conditionnnot to have occurredn```nnThis is about as unhelpful an error message as you can get.nnThe problem is that we havenn``` gonExpect(err).NotTo(HaveOccurred())n```nnpeppered throughout the code everywhere, and in this form, you can only figure out what failed if you read the Ginkgo error, remember which line has the line number you actually want, and then try to read surrounding code in that file.nnPossible improvements given in http://onsi.github.io/gomega/#handling-errors:n- Use `Succeed()`n- Annotate the assertionsn- Basically, do anything except just Expect(err).NotTo(HaveOccurred())nncc @kubernetes/sig-testing n

Thanks!rnrnIf the matter is security related, please disclose it privately via https://kubernetes.io/security/rn-->rnrnrn**What happened**:rnThis [PR](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/commit/30b0f8bf3bed2c1c146a85ecdfc6b9cb18c5a303) switches NodeLister to scheduler cache for `GetNodeInfo`. Rather, it returns a normal error:rnhttps://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/67d750bb2893d7a66d45d435dfc075fb17cc15ee/pkg/scheduler/internal/cache/cache.go#L696-L706rnrnHowever, we rely on the error type for logging, for example:rnhttps://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/7cb4850699a4a3c1008382c8b05f245b66ce19ad/pkg/scheduler/algorithm/predicates/predicates.go#L1386-L1394rn**What you expected to happen**:rnThe cache `GetNodeInfo()` should return IsNotFound error if applicable.rnrn**How to reproduce it (as minimally and precisely as possible)**:rnrn**Anything else we need to know?**:rnrnrn/sig schedulingrn@draveness  cc @ahg-g

issue.title: [framework] a consistent interface for plugin extended functionality
issue.body: **What would you like to be added**:rnA consistent way for adding extended functionality to plugins.rnrn**Why is this needed**:rnCurrently we have two types of plugins that support adding some sort of optional functionality: PreFilter allow adding 'AddPod/RemovePod' implementations through an 'Updater' interface, while Score includes a NormalizeScore, which must be implemented, but plugins that don't require it can return nil.rnrnThe two cases above support adding 'optional' functionality in different ways, what I suggest we do is have a common pattern, with common naming conventions to support that:rnrnAny plugin that needs an extended functionality should define an ```_PluginName_Extensions``` interface, and have a method named ```Extensions()``` that returns the interface or nil if the plugin does not implement those extensions.rnrnIf we do that for PreFilter and Score plugins, it would look like this:rnrn```rntype PreFilterExtensions interface {rntAddPod(pc *PluginContext, podToSchedule *v1.Pod, podToAdd *v1.Pod, nodeInfo *schedulernodeinfo.NodeInfo) *StatusrntRemovePod(pc *PluginContext, podToSchedule *v1.Pod, podToRemove *v1.Pod, nodeInfo *schedulernodeinfo.NodeInfo) *Statusrn}rnrntype PreFilterPlugin interface {rntPluginrntPreFilter(pc *PluginContext, p *v1.Pod) *StatusrntExtensions() PreFilterExtensionsrn}rnrnrntype ScoreExtensions interface {rn    NormalizeScore(pc *PluginContext, p *v1.Pod, scores NodeScoreList) *Statusrn}rnrntype ScorePlugin interface {rntPluginrn        Score(pc *PluginContext, p *v1.Pod, nodeName string) (int, *Status)rntExtensions() PreFilterExtensionsrn}rn```rnrnOne concern here is that if the plugin wants to implement a single method of the extensions interface, they it will have to implement all the extensions methods, but i think that is fine since we don't expect to have many methods anyways.rnrn

issue.title: Add-On manager should not be creating kube-system namespace
issue.body: **What happened**:rnAdd-on manager uses kubectl apply to create the kube-system namespace at start-up. rnThis is redundant because the kube-apiserver creates the namespace in NewBootstrapController. rnThis is a problem because if someone uses apply to make changes to the kube-system namespace, the add-on manager will wipe out these changes. rnrn**What you expected to happen**:rnKube-APIServer has the sole responsibility of creating the kube-system namespace.rnrn**How to reproduce it (as minimally and precisely as possible)**:rnkubectl apply a label to the kube-system namespace.rnrestart the add-on manager.rnNote the labels have been removed.rnrn**Anything else we need to know?**:rn/sig api-machineryrnrn**Environment**:rn- Kubernetes version (use `kubectl version`):rn- Cloud provider or hardware configuration:rn- OS (e.g: `cat /etc/os-release`):rn- Kernel (e.g. `uname -a`):rn- Install tools:rn- Others:rn

issue.title: Creating selectors is expensive in EndpointsController
issue.body: When profiling scalability tests at large scale, it appears that the function ``` SelectorFromValidatedSet``` can consume even 10% of cpu.rnIn the profiles it's coming purely from the GetPodServices in EndpointsController.rnrnThe reason for that is for every single call of GetPodServices:rnhttps://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/pkg/controller/endpoint/endpoints_controller.go#L170rnfor every single service in that namespace we build the selector from scratch:rnhttps://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/staging/src/k8s.io/client-go/listers/core/v1/service_expansion.go#L49rnrnEven though a single such operation is not very expensive, the amount of that is resulting in significant percentage of overall cpu usage.rnrnrnLonger-term solution is to do exactly what was done e.g. for ReplicaSet:rnhttps://github.com/kubernetes/api/blob/master/apps/v1/types.go#L723rn - use appropriate type for the selector once we create v2 Service API.rnrnThat would mean that store-in-memory services would have the selector already created, so it would eliminate that completely.rnrnI'm wondering if there is something we can do here more short-term.rnrn@kubernetes/sig-network-misc @freehan rn@kubernetes/sig-scalability-misc rn

issue.title: kube-proxy: ipv4/ipv6 mix crashes: KUBE-MARK-DROP':No such file or directory
issue.body: <!-- Please use this template while reporting a bug and provide as much info as possible. Not doing so may result in your bug not being addressed in a timely manner. Thanks!-->rnrnHi there,rnrnI'm not entirely sure if this is a bug or a funny configuration fault. Since that exact configuration worked before, I'm still reporting it.rnrn**What happened**:rnrnHaving mixed IPv4 and IPv6 addresses for pods prevented `kube-proxy` (in `iptables` mode) from creating iptables rules. Logged was an error from iptables-save: `Couldn't load target 'KUBE-MARK-DROP':No such file or directory`.rnrnSince there weren't a lot iptables rules written before the crashing command, network was completely down on that node.rnrnThis problem only affected a single node of my 4 node cluster (3 controllers which are also workers, one additional worker). Affected node was a controller node.rnrn**What you expected to happen**:rnrnCreate iptables rules as the cluster did before I started with the upgrades.rnrn**How to reproduce it (as minimally and precisely as possible)**:rnrnI started today with upgrading my cluster from 1.10.11 to 1.13.2 (installing every latest patch version for every minor in order). This problem started shortly after rolling out 1.12.5 after a node had an unrelated problem and had to be restarted. I think that reboot only uncovered the bug and the other nodes would also be affected after a reboot (or `kube-proxy --cleanup`).rnrnI had a funny-but-working config. My containers all have IPv4 addresses, but kubelet was configured to use the IPv6 address of the node (`--node-ip`, `--address`). This resulted in Pods created by a DaemonSet having IPv6 addresses.rnrnThat exact configuration worked on 1.10.11 and broke somewhere newer. The versions installed today before seeing the bug were 1.10.12, 1.11.7 and 1.12.5. rnrnFixing the kubelet config to use the IPv4 node address in the flags given above, restarting all kubelets and kube-proxies and then deleting all pods created by DaemonSets fixed the issue.rnrnrn**Anything else we need to know?**:rnrn**Environment**: rn- Kubernetes version (use `kubectl version`): stated abovern- Cloud provider or hardware configuration: virtual machines, different specsrn- OS (e.g. from /etc/os-release): Debian Stretch (current stable)rn- Kernel (e.g. `uname -a`): 4.9.0-8-amd64 (debian stretch kernel)rn- Install tools: custom playbooks for Ansible, can be provided with history regarding this bugrn- Others: no CNI plugin but static routesrn

issue.title: Need NodePort test for mixed-OS clusters
issue.body: We need a test case that will verify that NodePort works on all nodes in the cluster for a Windows application.rnrnHere's an example manual test:rnrnRun `kubectl create -f` with this yamlrnrn```yamlrnapiVersion: apps/v1rnkind: Deploymentrnmetadata:rn  name: iis-2019rn  labels:rn    app: iis-2019rnspec:rn  replicas: 1rn  template:rn    metadata:rn      name: iis-2019rn      labels:rn        app: iis-2019rn    spec:rn      containers:rn      - name: iisrn        image: mcr.microsoft.com/windows/servercore/iis:windowsservercore-ltsc2019rn        resources:rn          limits:rn            cpu: 1rn            memory: 800mrn          requests:rn            cpu: .1rn            memory: 300mrn        ports:rn          - containerPort: 80rn      nodeSelector:rn        'beta.kubernetes.io/os': windowsrn  selector:rn    matchLabels:rn      app: iis-2019rn---rnapiVersion: v1rnkind: Servicernmetadata:rn  name: iisrnspec:rn  type: NodePortrn  ports:rn  - protocol: TCPrn    port: 80rn  selector:rn    app: iis-2019rn```rnrnOnce the pod is running, get the nodeport and make sure it's accessible on each node IP for that port.rnrnrn```rn$ kubectl get svcrnNAME         TYPE        CLUSTER-IP   EXTERNAL-IP   PORT(S)        AGErniis          NodePort    10.0.88.64   <none>        80:30220/TCP   10mrnkubernetes   ClusterIP   10.0.0.1     <none>        443/TCP        10drnazureuser@k8s-master-30163644-0:~$ kubectl get node -o widernNAME                        STATUS   ROLES   AGE   VERSION   INTERNAL-IP   EXTERNAL-IP   OS-IMAGE                    KERNEL-VERSION   CONTAINER-RUNTIMErn3016k8s010                  Ready    agent   10d   v1.13.2   10.240.0.35   <none>        Windows Server Datacenter   10.0.17763.253rn                            docker://18.9.0rn3016k8s011                  Ready   agent   10d   v1.13.2   10.240.0.96   <none>   Windows Server Datacenter   10.0.17763.253rn                            docker://18.9.0rnk8s-linuxpool1-30163644-0   Ready   agent    10d   v1.13.2   10.240.0.4     <none>   Ubuntu 16.04.5 LTS   4.15.0-1036-azure   docker://3.0.1rnk8s-linuxpool1-30163644-1   Ready   agent    10d   v1.13.2   10.240.0.127   <none>   Ubuntu 16.04.5 LTS   4.15.0-1036-azure   docker://3.0.1rnk8s-master-30163644-0       Ready   master   10d   v1.13.2   10.255.255.5   <none>   Ubuntu 16.04.5 LTS   4.15.0-1036-azure   docker://3.0.1rnazureuser@k8s-master-30163644-0:~$ curl -s -o /dev/null -w '%{http_code}' http://10.240.0.35:30220rn200azureuser@k8s-master-30163644-0:~$ curl -s -o /dev/null -w '%{http_code}' http://10.240.0.96:30220rn200azureuser@k8s-master-30163644-0:~$ curl -s -o /dev/null -w '%{http_code}' http://10.240.0.4:30220rn200azureuser@k8s-master-30163644-0:~$ curl -s -o /dev/null -w '%{http_code}' http://10.240.0.127:30220rn200rn```rnrn/good-first-issuern/kind testrn/sig windowsrn

issue.title: [scheduler cleanup phase 2]: Move compatibility_test.go to `pkg/scheduler/api`
issue.body: **PLEASE COORDINATE WITH SIG-SCHEDULING BEFORE WORKING ON THIS ISSUE.** We want to avoid the situation where two people accidentally start work on the same fix.rnrnMain tracking issue: https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/issues/68951rnrnIf you contributed in phase 1, please give others a chance before claiming this issue. You can also help out by reviewing the phase 2 PRs.rnrnrnThe tests in `pkg/scheduler/algorithmprovider/defaults/compatibility_test.go` ensure backwards compatibility with the types in `pkg/scheduler/api`. It makes more sense for these tests to live in that package.rnrn/sig schedulingrn/kind cleanuprn/helprn/good-first-issue

issue.title: [scheduler cleanup phase 2]: Move predicate and priority registration into their own packages
issue.body: **PLEASE COORDINATE WITH SIG-SCHEDULING BEFORE WORKING ON THIS ISSUE.** We want to avoid the situation where two people accidentally start work on the same fix.rnrnMain tracking issue: https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/issues/68951rnrnIf you contributed in phase 1, please give others a chance before claiming this issue. You can also help out by reviewing the phase 2 PRs.rnrnrnThe package `pkg/scheduler/algorithmprovider/defaults` contains `init()` code that makes several calls into `factory.RegisterFitPredicate` and similar functions. The code that registers all predicates should be moved into `pkg/scheduler/algorithm/predicates` along with the call to `factory.RegisterPredicateMetadataProducerFactory`. The above also applies to priorities, whose code belongs in `pkg/scheduler/algorithm/priorities`.rnrnrnWhen this is done, the only `init()` code in the `defaults` package should be to `factory.RegisterAlgorithmProvider`.rnrnrnNote: Algorithm providers are just sets of strings, so the `defaults` package doesnu2019t need to have any side effects beyond registering the two algorithm providers.rnrnrnOther Note: I think `ApplyFeatureGates()` should be refactored away as part of https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/issues/68957.rnrn/sig schedulingrn/kind cleanuprn/helprn/good-first-issue

issue.title: [RFE] Allow to override default AWS endpoint
issue.body: <!-- Please only use this template for submitting enhancement requests -->rnrnWhen deploying kubernetes in AWS cloud provider it is assumed the AWS cloud is not disconnected [1]. In case the assumption is violated, the deployment fails as the default configuration sets the default endpoint DNS suffix to `amazonaws.com` [2].rnrn**What would you like to be added**:rnrnExtend the aws cloud provider initialization with configurable aws DNS suffix endpoint. Currently, the code creates a session (by invoking `session.NewSession(&aws.Config{})`, see [3]) that could be extended into:rnrn```gornsess, err := session.NewSession(&aws.Config{rntEndpointResolver: endpoints.ResolverFunc(myCustomResolver),rn})rn```rnrnas described in [4]. There are other places where the change needs to be applied:rn- for `LoadBalancing`: https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/f2c9eb860fd89acab5d587122ff77d8bf013b9b7/pkg/cloudprovider/providers/aws/aws.go#L673rn- for `Autoscaling`: https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/f2c9eb860fd89acab5d587122ff77d8bf013b9b7/pkg/cloudprovider/providers/aws/aws.go#L708rn- othersrnrn**Why is this needed**:rnrnSo the Kubernetes can be deployed in air-gapped AWS regions.rnrn**Links**rnrn[1] https://digitalageexperts.com/how-are-aws-private-air-gapped-regions-different/rn[2] https://github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go/blob/475409399d0f8a680b6c68fcd49be984e36d5d66/aws/endpoints/defaults.go#L212rn[3] https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/f2c9eb860fd89acab5d587122ff77d8bf013b9b7/pkg/cloudprovider/providers/aws/aws.go#L959rn[4] https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sdk-for-go/api/aws/endpoints/rnrn<!-- DO NOT EDIT BELOW THIS LINE -->rn/kind feature

issue.title: Some commands do not show glog flags
issue.body: ```rn$ hyperkube apiserver --help 2>&1 | grep -i 'log level'rn$ hyperkube controller-manager --help 2>&1 | grep -i 'log level'rn$ hyperkube cloud-controller-manager --help 2>&1 | grep -i 'log level'rn$ hyperkube kubelet --help 2>&1 | grep -i 'log level'rn  -v, --v Level   log level for V logsrn$ hyperkube proxy --help 2>&1 | grep -i 'log level'rn  -v, --v Level   log level for V logsrn$ hyperkube scheduler --help 2>&1 | grep -i 'log level'rn  -v, --v Level   log level for V logsrn```rnrnSame problem with the non hyperkube binaries too:rn```rn$ ./kube-apiserver --help 2>&1 | grep -i 'log level'rn$ ./kube-controller-manager --help 2>&1 | grep -i 'log level'rn$ ./cloud-controller-manager --help 2>&1 | grep -i 'log level'rn$ ./kubelet --help 2>&1 | grep -i 'log level'rn  -v, --v Level   log level for V logsrn$ ./kube-proxy --help 2>&1 | grep -i 'log level'rn  -v, --v Level   log level for V logsrn$ ./kube-scheduler --help 2>&1 | grep -i 'log level'rn  -v, --v Level   log level for V logsrn```

issue.title: Add volume test cases for Windows
issue.body: We need test cases for Windows volume mapping permissions (read-only / read-write) instead of Linux permissions. They should only run with the ginkgo focus `--node-os-distro=windows` set.rnrnThe test cases needed are:rn1. Create a pod with a host mapped volume mapped read-only. Files should be able to be read, but not writtenrn2. Same test case with emptydirrn3. Create a pod with one host volume but different mount permissions for each container. One container should be read only, the other should be read-writernrnrnThis will replace the similar test cases on Linux:rnrn```rn[sig-storage] EmptyDir volumes  should support (root,0644,default) [NodeConformance] [Conformance]rn[sig-storage] EmptyDir volumes  should support (root,0666,default) [NodeConformance] [Conformance]rn[sig-storage] EmptyDir volumes  should support (root,0666,tmpfs) [NodeConformance] [Conformance]rn```rnrnrn/kind test rn/sig windowsrn

issue.title: Remove hyperkube short aliases
issue.body: rnHyperkube supports a number of short aliases for commands, such as `apiserver`, `controller-manager`, `proxy`, `scheduler`, etc, rather than the longer `kube-apiserver`, `kube-controller-manager`, `kube-proxy`, `kube-scheduler` etc.rnrnThere are comments indicating this is 'unfortunate'rnhttps://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/ef195428a0c5b16e3f3621b7fe59fa151ca28929/cmd/hyperkube/main.go#L90-L94rnrnand we still currently create these aliases in the hyperkube docker image:rnhttps://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/ef195428a0c5b16e3f3621b7fe59fa151ca28929/cluster/images/hyperkube/Dockerfile#L17-L29rnrnIt'd be nice to simplify this, assuming we can find all uses of the short aliases and remove them.rnrn/kind cleanuprnrnNot sure which sig should own this, so tagging a few.rn/sig architecture cluster-lifecycle clirnrncc @luxas @mikedanese

issue.title: Use http.Error() instead of writing responses directly
issue.body: There are several places where we return errors from an HTTP server by writing the error code and message directly. We should standardize on using [http.Error ](https://golang.org/pkg/net/http/?#Error)everywhere to pick up the 'text/plain' and 'nosniff' content type headers.rnrnHere's a [cs.k8s.io query](https://cs.k8s.io/?q=%5C.WriteHeader%5C(http%5C.Status%5B%5EO%5D&i=nope&files=%5E(pkg%7Ccmd%7Cstaging)&repos=kubernetes/kubernetes) @tallclair gave me that probably catches most of the places where we are doing this.rnrnThe unit test ones would be nice to fix too, but the more important ones are the non-test code:rn- [ ] pkg/controller/garbagecollector/dump.gorn- [ ] pkg/kubectl/proxy/proxy_server.gorn- [ ] pkg/kubelet/server/remotecommand/httpstream.gorn- [ ] pkg/proxy/healthcheck/healthcheck.gorn- [ ] staging/src/k8s.io/apimachinery/pkg/util/httpstream/httpstream.gorn- [ ] staging/src/k8s.io/apimachinery/pkg/util/httpstream/spdy/upgrade.gorn- [ ] staging/src/k8s.io/apimachinery/pkg/util/proxy/upgradeaware.gorn- [ ] staging/src/k8s.io/apiserver/pkg/endpoints/handlers/responsewriters/writers.gorn- [ ] staging/src/k8s.io/apiserver/pkg/server/filters/cors.gorn- [ ] staging/src/k8s.io/apiserver/pkg/server/filters/maxinflight.gorn- [ ] staging/src/k8s.io/apiserver/pkg/server/filters/timeout.go

issue.title: [scheduler cleanup phase 1]: Simplify kube-scheduleru2019s server.go `run`
issue.body: **PLEASE COORDINATE WITH SIG-SCHEDULING BEFORE WORKING ON THIS ISSUE.** We want to avoid the situation where two people accidentally start work on the same fix.rnMain tracking issue: https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/issues/68951rnrnIn `cmd/kube-scheduler/app/server.go` the `NewSchedulerCommand()` function creates a `cobra.Command` object and populates the `Run` field with an anonymous function. At the end of that function, `Run()` is called, which contains the rest of our startup logic.rnrnrnRather than split this across two functions, we should put all the startup logic in one named function called `run` (not `Run`) so that constructing the `cobra.Command` object is much more plain.rnrn/sig schedulingrn/kind cleanuprn/helprn/good-first-issuern

issue.title: update doc.go in staging/ repositories
issue.body: - Look at one of the directories under staging/src/k8s.io/ (Please don't pick more than one directory for one PR as it will cause issues for reviewers)rn- Find all the files named `doc.go` (example find staging/src/k8s.io/client-go/ -name doc.go)rn- See the following link it has a `// import 'k8s.io/client-go/tools/remotecommand'` this tells tools how this package needs to be imported. So we should ensure that each doc.go has an importrn   https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/1fc36a5743bc02d62ddaac6cd41b71f0ef191ce2/staging/src/k8s.io/client-go/tools/remotecommand/doc.go#L20rn- Add a description appropriate to the package (similar to the one below)rn   https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/1fc36a5743bc02d62ddaac6cd41b71f0ef191ce2/staging/src/k8s.io/client-go/tools/remotecommand/doc.go#L17-L19rn- Look through sub directories and see if there are any other important directories that are likely to be used by outside users and add a doc.gornrnWhy are we doing this?rn- We perfer to use vanity urls instead of directly using github.com to refer to code, so this helps ensure that tools honor our wish. See https://golang.org/doc/go1.4#canonicalimportsrn- It would be good to have some package level documentation since these directories under staging/ are meant to be for use by folks outside of kubernetes github org.rnrn/good-first-issue

issue.title: Upate import-boss restrictions
issue.body: `hack/verify-import-boss.sh` is a tool we use to reduce technical debt around rampant interdepencies between packages in the main k/k repository.rnrnThe tool uses a file `.import-restrictions` in some directories that verify-import-boss.sh then uses to check. The syntax for the file is here:rnhttps://github.com/kubernetes/code-generator/blob/master/cmd/import-boss/main.go#L32-L52rnrnWe currently have the following `.import-restrictions` in the main k/k repository:rn```rn[dims@dims-mac 19:00] ~/go/src/k8s.io/kubernetes u27e9 find  . -name .import-res*rn./cmd/kubeadm/.import-restrictionsrn./pkg/.import-restrictionsrn./pkg/api/testing/.import-restrictionsrn./pkg/client/clientset_generated/.import-restrictionsrn./pkg/controller/.import-restrictionsrn./pkg/kubectl/.import-restrictionsrn./pkg/kubemark/.import-restrictionsrn./pkg/printers/.import-restrictionsrn./pkg/printers/internalversion/.import-restrictionsrn./staging/src/k8s.io/apiserver/.import-restrictionsrn./staging/src/k8s.io/code-generator/cmd/lister-gen/.import-restrictionsrn```rnWhat needs to be done?rn- Open up the `.import-restrictions` file, check if `AllowedPrefixes` under different `Rules` are correct. rn  - The packages listed are still being used in the code under the pacakgern  - If there are outside packages that are used, but not listed under `AllowedPrefixes` then add those packagesrn- Possibly add new .import-restrictions for different directories under `/staging/src/k8s.io/` so we can be sure each directory under that is self-contained.rn- If the .import-restrictions looks correct, then leave a comment in this issue so others don't duplicate the work. If you want to work on a specific file, leave a note so others don't spend their time on the same work.rnrnPrior art (see how we did this in earlier PRs):rn- https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/35148rn- https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/53458rn- https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/63740rnrn/good-first-issuern

issue.title: HPA metrics client assumes all resources are namespaced
issue.body: /kind bugrnrnThe HPA controller's metrics client currently assumes all objects referenced in the `Object` metrics type are namespaced (unless it's namespaces themselves).  This is wrong -- we should be using a RESTMapper to figure out the scope.rnrnWhen we do this, we need to make certain that we scope down the HPA's default permissions so that a normal user can't use the HPA to discover metrics that they otherwise shouldn't be able to (e.g. node metrics).

issue.title: clients: port exec-based client auth provider to non go-lang clients
issue.body: With 1.10, this exec-based client auth credential provider alpha feature was introduced  [kubernetes/features#541](https://github.com/kubernetes/features/issues/541) for client-go.  Kubernetes project also [officially supports](https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/client-libraries/) [Java](https://github.com/kubernetes-client/java/), [Python](https://github.com/kubernetes-client/python), [dotnet](https://github.com/kubernetes-client/csharp), and [Javascript](https://github.com/kubernetes-client/javascript) clients. Exec-based auth plugin should be supported by these client libraries in addition to client-go.rnrn/kind featurern/sig api-machineryrn

issue.title: Literal '$Format' in API server logs
issue.body: /kind bugrnrn**What happened**:rnrnI see the literal string '(dollar_sign)Format' in the API server logs:rnrn```rnI1101 07:05:53.364424       7 wrap.go:42] GET /api/v1/namespaces/kube-system/services/default-http-backend: (1.73008ms) 404 [[glbc/v0.0.0 (linux/amd64) kubernetes/$Format] 127.0.0.1:52702]rn```rnrnNote that most lines are fine, it seems that just some binaries don't have the placeholder substituted:rnrn```rnI1101 07:06:29.825192       7 wrap.go:42] POST /apis/authorization.k8s.io/v1beta1/subjectaccessreviews: (361.716u00b5s) 201 [[kube-controller-manager/v1.9.0 (linux/amd64) kubernetes/7f9f847/system:serviceaccount:kube-system:certificate-controller] [::1]:50612]rn```rnrn**What you expected to happen**:rnrnExpected to see kubernetes commit ID or tag name in all cases.rnrn**How to reproduce it (as minimally and precisely as possible)**:rnrnRun an e2e test, grep for Format in API server log.rnrn**Anything else we need to know?**:rnrn**Environment**:rn- Kubernetes version (use `kubectl version`): masterrn- Cloud provider or hardware configuration: GCErn

issue.title: Sign error in comment on resource.ScaledValue
issue.body: <!-- This form is for bug reports and feature requests ONLY! rnrnIf you're looking for help check [Stack Overflow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/kubernetes) and the [troubleshooting guide](https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/debug-application-cluster/troubleshooting/).rn-->rnrn**Is this a BUG REPORT or FEATURE REQUEST?**:rnrn> Uncomment only one, leave it on its own line: rn>rn/kind bugrn> /kind featurernrnrn**What happened**:rnI invoked `ScaledValue(-9)` on a resource.Quantity, and got a result that was multiplied by a factor of 10^9.rnrn**What you expected to happen**:rnI expected to get a value that was multiplied by a factor of 10^-9, because the comment says 'ScaledValue returns the value of ceil(q * 10^scale)'.rnrn**How to reproduce it (as minimally and precisely as possible)**:rn```rnq, _ := resource.ParseQuantity('10')rni := q.ScaledValue(-1)rn```rnprint `i`.  You will find it is 100, not 1.rnrn**Anything else we need to know?**:rnLook at the meaning of the `AsScaledInt64` method invoked in the integer case.  This method returns the quantity expressed as a multiple of 10^scale.  10 is 100 tenths.rnrn**Environment**:rn- Kubernetes version (use `kubectl version`): masterrnrn

issue.title: kubectl --v= is underdocumented
issue.body: _(Comes from user)_nnThe most important thing for cloud support is insight, logs, verbosity. The description of the `--v` argument reads:n`--v=0: log level for V logs`n- What are the different log levels?n- What level is most useful to see all API calls?n- What is 'V'?n- What would be a useful standard reply to a customer? 'Please re-run this command with --v=9 and send me the output'nnWith gcloud I normally ask for the output of `--log-http --verbosity=debug`.nn@kubernetes/kubectl @ymqytw @pwittrock n

issue.title: Cleanup: Audit log and error capitalization
issue.body: Generally: log-lines start with capital letters; error strings do not (unless it starts with an acronym like IP).  We're not consistent with this.  It should be relatively easy to audit these and fix-up.n

issue.body: iptables should receive some interface that dbus happens to implement instead of coupling.n
